articles.headline: Ukraine Tensions Spike as West Accuses Russia of Lying About Troop Withdrawal
articles.snippet: As Russia stoked hopes of a diplomatic solution and claimed to be pulling back forces from the Ukrainian border, U.S. and NATO officials accused Moscow of building up troops instead.
articles.abstract: As Russia stoked hopes of a diplomatic solution and claimed to be pulling back forces from the Ukrainian border, U.S. and NATO officials accused Moscow of building up troops instead.
articles.lead_paragraph: KYIV, Ukraine — Tensions over Ukraine abruptly ratcheted up on Wednesday as Western officials accused Russia of lying about whether it had really begun pulling back troops from the Ukrainian border.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer, Anton Troianovski and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Effort to Weaken Press Protections Isn’t Likely to End With Palin Case
articles.snippet: Lawyers sympathetic to revisiting libel law say several cases in the courts could be used to re-examine longstanding Supreme Court precedent.
articles.abstract: Lawyers sympathetic to revisiting libel law say several cases in the courts could be used to re-examine longstanding Supreme Court precedent.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: For Trump, a Perilous Exclamation Point to Years of Wealth Inflation
articles.snippet: The former president has spent decades inventing facts and figures to suit his needs. Now, dropped by his accountants, he is making new claims.
articles.abstract: The former president has spent decades inventing facts and figures to suit his needs. Now, dropped by his accountants, he is making new claims.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Tuesday evening, former President Donald J. Trump, rattled by news that his longtime accountants had declared that years of his financial statements were not reliable, issued a statement of self-defense with new claims about his wealth.

articles.headline: Do You Know Who That Worker You Just Hired Really Is?
articles.snippet: Employers love to talk about “authenticity.” But psychologists say nearly everyone uses some form of deception to get a job.
articles.abstract: Employers love to talk about “authenticity.” But psychologists say nearly everyone uses some form of deception to get a job.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was as if a “Seinfeld” plot met John le Carré.

articles.headline: Vulnerable to the Virus, High-Risk Americans Feel Pain as the U.S. Moves On
articles.snippet: Transplant recipients, cancer patients and millions of other Americans with risk factors feel ignored and abandoned as their neighbors, and their government, seek a return to normal.
articles.abstract: Transplant recipients, cancer patients and millions of other Americans with risk factors feel ignored and abandoned as their neighbors, and their government, seek a return to normal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Denisse Takes’s world is very small these days. She makes a living by producing songs from her living room, plays “Animal Crossing” online with friends and leaves her home in Burbank, Calif., only occasionally to walk her dog.
articles.byline: By Amanda Morris and Maggie Astor

articles.headline: The World Needs What Intel Makes. Can It Make a Comeback?
articles.snippet: Patrick Gelsinger is back running a company he first joined at 18. The chip maker was a Silicon Valley titan that lost its luster. As the world craves chips, the C.E.O. has faith he can fix it all.
articles.abstract: Patrick Gelsinger is back running a company he first joined at 18. The chip maker was a Silicon Valley titan that lost its luster. As the world craves chips, the C.E.O. has faith he can fix it all.
articles.lead_paragraph: Patrick Gelsinger was 18 years old and four months into an entry-level job at Intel when he heard a pivotal sermon at a Silicon Valley church in February 1980. There, a minister quoted Jesus from the Book of Revelation.

articles.headline: The $1.7 Billion Student Loan Deal That Was Too Good to Be True
articles.snippet: The settlement was portrayed as a win-win for 39 states and the loan giant Navient. But thousands who received predatory loans will still have to pay.
articles.abstract: The settlement was portrayed as a win-win for 39 states and the loan giant Navient. But thousands who received predatory loans will still have to pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: After years of struggling to make payments that hardly put a dent in the loans she took out to attend a now defunct arts school, Victoria Linssen saw a glimmer of hope. A deal last month between 39 states and Navient, a student lending giant accused of unfairly ensnaring borrowers like her, would wipe away $1.7 billion in private student loans.
